predictions.text: The U.S. (White House, DoD, or State) will publicly announce a pause, suspension, or reduction of at least $1.0 billion (USD) in planned Ukraine security assistance (weapons/munitions/training), by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if an official U.S. government statement/press release (White House, DoD, State, or OMB) specifies a pause/suspension/reduction totaling >=$1.0B of planned Ukraine security aid; or Reuters/Bloomberg/WSJ/FT reports the same citing named officials/documents. Otherwise NO.
evidence: NYT (2025-12-30) reports fraying U.S.-Ukraine ties increasing uncertainty for military aid: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/12/30/world/europe/ukraine-us-russia-takeaways.html
monitoring_signals: DoD/State press briefings referencing Ukraine aid ‘review’, ‘conditionality’, or ‘pause’
OMB apportionment delays or reprogramming notifications related to Ukraine
Congressional letters/hearings indicating withheld tranches or delayed drawdowns
Major wire-service scoops (Reuters/Bloomberg) on halted shipments
predictions.rationale: Political friction and shifting priorities raise the odds of an explicit aid slowdown; the threshold is set high to avoid counting routine timing slippage.

predictions.text: Israel will formally suspend, revoke, or deny renewal of authorization/registration for at least one major international humanitarian NGO operating in Gaza (excluding UNRWA), with the NGO publicly confirming disruption of Gaza operations due to the Israeli action, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if (a) Israel’s government (COGAT/Defense Ministry/Interior/Justice or published regulation/notice) announces or is credibly reported (Reuters/AP/AFP/NYT/FT/WSJ/Bloomberg) to have suspended/revoked/denied authorization for a named NGO (e.g., MSF, IRC, NRC, Save the Children, Mercy Corps), and (b) the NGO states this action disrupted its Gaza operations. Otherwise NO.
evidence: NYT (2025-12-30) reports new Israeli rules could suspend Gaza aid groups: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/12/30/world/middleeast/gaza-aid-group-suspensions-israel.html
monitoring_signals: COGAT policy updates on NGO access/visas/registrations
NGO statements about license/registration denial or staff visa refusals
Israeli court filings related to NGO status
Diplomatic protests from EU/UN about NGO operating permissions
predictions.rationale: Regulatory tightening plus ongoing conflict increases the chance at least one prominent NGO faces a concrete authorization action beyond UNRWA-specific dynamics.

predictions.text: The U.S. Treasury (OFAC) will announce a Venezuela-related sanctions package designating at least 20 individuals/entities in a single action (same press release/date), by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if OFAC issues a single Venezuela-related action with >=20 new designations (individuals and/or entities) disclosed on the same date/press release; counts only new SDN/NS-MBS additions. Otherwise NO.
evidence: CNBC (2025-12-30) notes widened U.S. sanctions targeting Iranian and Venezuelan networks: https://www.cnbc.com/2025/12/30/us-iran-venezuela-sanctions.html
NYT (2025-12-30) reports a CIA strike in Venezuela signaling higher confrontation risk: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/12/30/us/politics/trump-venezuela-drone-strike-attack.html
monitoring_signals: OFAC press releases mentioning Venezuela, PDVSA networks, or shipping/trading intermediaries
Treasury/State joint statements on Venezuela enforcement
SDN list update volume spikes tied to Venezuela
Reuters/Bloomberg reporting on pending ‘major’ Venezuela sanctions rollouts
predictions.rationale: Escalating confrontation and prior multi-target actions make a larger batch designation plausible; the >=20 threshold avoids counting small, routine updates.

predictions.text: OpenAI will close and publicly confirm (or be credibly reported by Reuters/Bloomberg/FT/WSJ) a new debt financing and/or revolving credit facility totaling at least $5.0 billion (USD) in committed amount, by 2026-09-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if OpenAI announces, or a top-tier outlet (Reuters/Bloomberg/FT/WSJ) reports with specific size, that OpenAI has closed a debt raise and/or committed credit facility with aggregate committed amount >=$5.0B. Must be committed/closed (not just ‘in talks’). Otherwise NO.
evidence: CNBC (2025-12-30) reports SoftBank fully funded a $40B OpenAI investment, underscoring capital intensity: https://www.cnbc.com/2025/12/30/softbank-openai-investment.html
The Economist (2025-12-30) highlights OpenAI cash burn as a key 2026 bubble risk: https://www.economist.com/leaders/2025/12/30/openais-cash-burn-will-be-one-of-the-big-bubble-questions-of-2026
monitoring_signals: Reports of OpenAI negotiating bank facilities or issuing private credit
Credit-market chatter about large AI borrower syndications
OpenAI disclosures about compute capex commitments and cash runway
SoftBank/Microsoft-related financing updates affecting OpenAI capital structure
predictions.rationale: Frontier-model scaling is capital intensive; incremental equity may be supplemented with structured debt/credit to fund compute and working capital through 2026.

predictions.text: Meta will launch a broadly available (not invite-only) consumer-facing AI agent in the U.S. that can autonomously execute at least one multi-step task (e.g., plan-and-book, shop-and-checkout, or schedule-and-confirm) across third-party websites or services, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if Meta (official blog/app release notes/press release) launches a U.S.-available agent feature that (a) is generally accessible, and (b) completes a multi-step task with third-party integration (APIs or web actions) beyond Meta’s own properties; corroborated by reputable tech press demos. Otherwise NO.
evidence: CNBC (2025-12-30) reports Meta’s acquisition of AI agent firm Manus, suggesting acceleration toward autonomous agents: https://www.cnbc.com/2025/12/30/meta-acquires-singapore-ai-agent-firm-manus-china-butterfly-effect-monicai.html
monitoring_signals: Meta product announcements about ‘agents’, ‘actions’, ‘skills’, or tool-use
App updates for WhatsApp/Instagram/Facebook mentioning bookings or purchases
Partnership announcements with travel, commerce, or scheduling providers
Developer platform updates enabling third-party agent actions
predictions.rationale: Acquisition-driven capability plus competitive pressure increases the chance of a real consumer agent rollout, but third-party execution and safety/compliance could delay general availability.

predictions.text: At least one major publicly traded China-focused EV maker (NIO, XPeng, Li Auto, Zeekr/Geely, Leapmotor, or BYD) will announce a single workforce reduction of at least 10% (or at least 10,000 employees) in a press release, filing, or Reuters/Bloomberg report citing the company, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if a named eligible company publicly discloses, or Reuters/Bloomberg reports citing company statements/documents, a headcount reduction meeting >=10% or >=10,000 employees executed as a single restructuring event (not cumulative attrition). Otherwise NO.
evidence: CNBC (2025-12-30) notes China’s EV sector may shift from boom to survival amid price wars and margin pressure: https://www.cnbc.com/2025/12/30/china-electric-car-2026-price-war-evs-sales-global-expansion-slowdown-price-war-2025.html
monitoring_signals: Earnings calls referencing ‘organizational optimization’ or ‘cost reset’
Chinese media and wire reports on layoffs at major EV OEMs
Supplier payment-term stress and factory utilization declines
Government signals reducing support or tightening financing
predictions.rationale: Price-war dynamics and margin compression often trigger large restructuring moves; the threshold focuses on unmistakably material layoffs.

predictions.text: NetBlocks (or a comparably cited internet-monitoring organization) will report a nationwide disruption in Iran reducing internet connectivity by at least 50% for 24+ consecutive hours, with major international media attribution to unrest/security measures, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if NetBlocks (or equivalent widely cited monitor) posts data showing Iran’s national connectivity down >=50% for >=24 hours, and at least one major outlet (Reuters/AP/AFP/NYT/FT/WSJ/Bloomberg) links it to unrest/security actions (not natural disasters). Otherwise NO.
evidence: NYT (2025-12-30) describes Iran’s currency crash/inflation driving protests into universities, elevating internal instability risk: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/12/30/world/middleeast/iran-protests-currency-inflation-universities.html
monitoring_signals: Protest escalations across multiple provinces/cities
Iranian government statements on ‘cybersecurity’ or ‘public order’ measures
NetBlocks and IODA anomaly alerts for Iran
Messaging-app throttling reports preceding wider shutdowns
predictions.rationale: Iran has precedent for large shutdowns during unrest, but timing is uncertain and policy may shift toward more targeted throttling instead of nationwide outages.

predictions.text: The Federal Reserve will cut the federal funds target range at least once (a reduction in either/both bounds) in any scheduled 2026 FOMC meeting, by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if the FOMC announces a lower target range than the immediately prior meeting at any point in 2026 (scheduled meetings only). Otherwise NO.
evidence: Fed minutes (2025-12-30) show officials balancing inflation risks vs slowing growth, consistent with potential easing later if data weaken: https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/pressreleases/monetary20251230a.htm
monitoring_signals: Core inflation trend and labor-market softening
Fed communications about ‘restrictive’ stance no longer needed
Futures-implied probability of cuts rising above 60%
Downside growth surprises (PMIs, payrolls, credit spreads)
predictions.rationale: With policy already restrictive and growth risks highlighted, at least one cut during 2026 is more likely than not, though inflation persistence remains a key counterweight.

predictions.text: South Africa’s government (DMRE/IPP Office) will award (preferred bidders announced) at least 2.0 GW of new utility-scale solar PV capacity in a single procurement round (or combined announcement explicitly tied to one round), by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if an official South African government announcement names preferred bidders/awards totaling >=2.0 GW solar PV (MW aggregated) tied to a specific procurement round (e.g., REIPPPP bid window). Otherwise NO.
evidence: NYT (2025-12-30) describes cheap solar reshaping African households and businesses, implying continued policy and investment momentum: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/12/30/climate/solar-south-africa-china.html
monitoring_signals: REIPPPP bid-window timelines and government gazettes
Eskom grid-connection capacity updates and curtailment rules
Financing announcements by DFIs and local banks for PV pipelines
Policy statements prioritizing load-shedding reduction via renewables
predictions.rationale: Solar economics and reliability needs support sizable awards, but transmission constraints, procurement delays, and political/administrative bottlenecks can push awards beyond 2026.
